context.text: Microgrids are formed when distributed generators (DGs), energy storage systems, and loads are clustered as a single controllable entity to operate either independently or in conjunction with the main grid [1]–[3].
Microgrids can provide strong support to the grid by alleviating stresses, reducing feeder losses, and improving reliability, efficiency, and scalability [1].

In centralized control, a high-bandwidth, point-to-point communication is required between the central controller and local DG control units [1], which increases the communication and computational costs [1], [5].

By contrast, the distributed control that utilizes a sparse communication network provides a promising solution [1], [2], in which each DG only has access to the information of itself and its neighboring DGs [6], reducing computational complexity and the requirements on communication network, and improving scalability, reliability, and resiliency to faults and unknown system parameters [1].

For the distributed control of AC microgrids, the droop-free distributed control has recently been proposed [1], [2] which successfully achieves the objectives of average voltage regulation and active-reactive power sharing among the DGs.
However, the control formulation in [1], [2] relies on extensive use of PI controllers and may not always theoretically guarantee convergence.

One of the earliest papers to study multiuser (MU) multicarrier SWIPT is [22], which examines a multiple-input single-output (MISO) SWIPT network employing subcarrier assignment through orthogonal frequency division multiple access (OFDMA).

For example, power allocation for an OFDMA-based MISO-SWIPT system is examined in [22], but the authors treat the beamforming vectors as given and convexify the problem by bounding the impact of interference.

OFDM-based SWIPT that supports multiple users relies on subcarrier assignment for multiple access [22], [25], [54], [55], but this is redundant if using beamforming since beamforming enables multiple access through spatial multiplexing.
The performance is then compared to that of an exhaustive search algorithm and another algorithm based on a similar system model [22] to that considered in this paper.
The proposed algorithm is compared to two alternative algorithms, i.e. the exhaustive search algorithm and a selected algorithm (P5.1) from [22], referred to as the Huang-Larsson algorithm.
The authors in [22] examine a system similar to that presented in this paper, but only optimize the power allocation while assuming the beamforming vectors are given.
Unlike the problem considered in this paper, [22] assumes the precoders are given before determining the power allocation and thus cannot use the MMSE precoder.

It has been recently demonstrated by the authors that highly sensitive reflective-mode phase-variation permittivity sensors can be implemented by cascading either a 90º high-impedance or a 180º low-impedance open-ended sensing line to a step-impedance line made of quarter-wavelength high/low impedance inverters [30].

The result is a fluidic sensor exhibiting high sensitivity, and resolution, by virtue of the high impedance 90º line section cascaded to the 180º sensing line, an aspect exhaustively discussed and justified in [30], and succinctly reviewed in the next section.

As discussed in [30], for sensitivity enhancement, the sensor must be designed with the sensing line exhibiting an electrical length of either 90º or 180º for the unperturbed state, i.e., when the fluidic channel contains pure wine (0% of ethanol).

For this electrical length for the unperturbed state, sensitivity optimization also requires a low characteristic impedance for the sensing line (contrarily, a high impedance sensing line is needed for an electrical length of 90º) [30].
Moreover, as demonstrated in [30], the sensitivity can be further enhanced by cascading 90º line sections with alternating low and high characteristic impedance.

context.text: Recently, a new approach based on the Hanai’s formula for complex dielectric mixtures was proposed in [14] to estimate water volume from water-containing multiphase flows,.

The work presented in [14] assumes that the mixture state of the water, either continuous or dispersed, is known, and different mathematical formulations are needed to determine water volume from water-dispersed or water-continuous two-phase flows.
Similarly, the method presented in [14] utilizes ECT sensors to obtain low-frequency measurements and exploits the Maxwell-Wagner-Sillars (MWS) effect to compute water volume fractions.

Previous studies have shown that, for spherically dispersed homogeneous mixtures, Hanai’s formula (an extension of Bruggeman’s formula) provides a better estimation of the electrical properties when compared to other mixture formulas [3], [4], [14].

Although the results suggest that these formulas can produce good estimate, in practice there are still some challenges to overcome for practical applications such as the need to assume a flow type (with water either as dispersed or continuous phase) a priori and the need for data calibration based on one known volume fraction data point for renormalized [14].
